metadata.title: Bacterial cellulose-polyaniline nano-biocomposite: A porous media hydrogel bioanode enhancing the performance of microbial fuel cell

sections.text:
lable at ScienceDirect
Contents lists avai
Journal of Power Sources
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate/ jpowsour
Bacterial cellulose-polyaniline nano-biocomposite: A porous media hydrogel bioanode enhancing the performance of microbial fuel cell
Mehrdad Mashkour a, Mostafa Rahimnejad a, *, Mahdi Mashkour b
a Biofuel and Renewable Energy Research Center, Department of Chemical Engineering, Babol Noshirvani University of Technology, Babol, Iran b Department of Wood Engineering and Technology, Faculty of Wood and Paper Engineering, Gorgan University of Agricultural Sciences and Natural Resources, Gorgan 49189-43464, Iran
h i g h l i g h t s
* Corresponding author. E-mail addresses: Rahimnejad_mostafa@yahoo
(M. Rahimnejad).
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jpowsour.2016.06.063 0378-7753/© 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
g r a p h i c a l a b s t r a c t
Bacterial Cellulose (BC) is proposed as a porous hydrogel scaffold for anode. Hydrogel nature of BC facilitates transferring nutrients for exoelectrogens. Polyaniline (PANI) is coated on BC’s fibers as a conductive catalyst. BC/PANI nano-biocomposite is used as a green novel anode in MFC. BC/PANI raises the output power of MFC from 1 to 117 mW/m2 compared to graphite.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 18 February 2016 Received in revised form 11 June 2016 Accepted 13 June 2016
Keywords: Microbial fuel cell Bacterial cellulose Polyaniline Hydrogel anode Power density Current density
a b s t r a c t
Microbial fuel cells (MFCs) are one of the possible renewable energy supplies which microorganisms play an active role in bio-oxidize reactions of a substrate such as glucose. Electrode materials and surface modifications are highly effective tools in enhancing MFCs’ Performance. In this study, new composite anodes are fabricated. Bacterial cellulose (BC) is used as continuous phase and polyaniline (PANI) as dispersed one which is synthesized by in situ chemical oxidative polymerization on BC’s fibers. With hydrogel nature of BC as a novel feature and polyaniline conductivity there meet the favorable conditions to obtain an active microbial biofilm on anode surface. Maximum power density of 117.76 mW/m2 in current density of 617 mA/m2 is achieved for BC/PANI anode. The amounts demonstrate a considerable enhancement compared with graphite plate (1 mW/m2 and 10 mA/m2).
© 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Microbial fuel cells (MFCs) are novel environmentally friendly devices which are able to generate electricity and treat organic
.com, Rahimnejad@nit.ac.ir
waste materials simultaneously [1e3]. In MFCs, exoelectrogenic microorganisms are the active biocatalysts decomposing organic substrates like glucose to electrons and protons in order to recover chemical energy of the waste materials in the form of electricity [4,5]. At a simple dual-chamber MFC, electrons move from anode electrode to external circuit and protons cross a proton exchange membrane (PEM) at the same time only to recombine with oxygen on cathode electrode surface in cathode compartment [6]. From
electricity generation point of view, power and current density are the most significant outputs of a MFC device. Among effective parameters on MFC’s performance, fabrication of novel anode materials is at the core attention of the recent studies [7e10].
It is worth noting that practical applicable anodes should have the properties of high conductivity, catalytic activity, biocompatibility, chemical stability and resistance to decomposition. Besides aforementioned properties, excellent anodes ideally crave porous structure for the internal bacterial biofilms to be formed on their surfaces with strong mechanical contact. As a result, extracellular electron transfer is facilitated. In an evolutionary development, various porous anodes have been employed in MFCs consisting of carbon cloth [11], carbon paper [12], carbon brush [13] and carbon felt [14]. In addition to carbon based materials, 3D SS materials are also used such as SS felt, SS foam [15,16]. On the other hand, as the dense microbial film happens to form on the anode surface, the nutrient transfer from substrate solved in anolyte to internal microorganisms becomes less. Hence, a decline in the biocatalytic activity of the microorganisms is observed leading to their inactivity and eventually to their spoilage. Inactive bacteria play a role of an electrical resistance layer and decrease electro active surface area of anode. In 2010, Xie, X., et al. purposed a macro porous 3D CNT-Textile as anode [10] which promoted active biofilm surface and facilitated electron transfer. Therefore, it would be of great use to employ an appropriate scaffold to improve the performance of the anode.
The intrinsic 3D network structure and superhydrophilic nature of the Bacterial cellulose (BC) fibers are highly acclaimed by researchers the world over [17,18]. Moreover, eco-friendly, high porosity and ultrafine mechanical properties of them have earned worldwide attention. As a promising scaffold for electrode fabrication, porous BC has been modified by conductive polymers such as polyaniline and polypyrrole and used in Li-ion batteries [19e21] and also super capacitors [22]. Conductive polymers because of excellent redox properties, conductivity, low cost, high environmental stability and trouble-less synthesis are applied widely in electrochemical systems [23].
In this study, we utilized in-situ polymerization of various amounts of aniline on BC fibers to fabricate BC/PANI nanobiocomposites. Then they were used as hydrogel bio anodes in a dual-chamber MFC. Hydrogel state of BC brings about a permanent and homogenous nutrient transfer to attached microbial biofilm and prepares favorable conditions for bacteria colonization and also prevents their spoilage. As a modifier, polyaniline provides BC with suitable conductivity. Such a conductive porous composite, like a supercapacitor, can facilitate the electron transfer from bacteria to external circuit. Therefore, the hydrogel bioanode is expected to improve the MFC’s performance.

sections.heading: 2.1. Synthesis of BC/PANI nano-biocomposite
sections.text:
The synthesis of polyaniline at BC was performed based on Muller et al. method [24]. Different volumes of Aniline (100, 200, 300 and 400 mL) were added to 10mL of 0.5MHCl aqueous solution and then themixturewas stirred for 10min. Sheets of non-dried BC (4 cm 5 cm) were prepared from Nano Novin Polymer Co. (Iran). Then, theywere immersed in aniline solution for 1 h to becomewet with aniline completely. Therefore, water in the BC was replaced by aniline. Afterward, FeCl3 aqueous solution as initiator of polymerization reaction was added to provide a constant mole ratio of 1:2 aniline: FeCl3. The reaction was carried out at 5 C on a shaker for 18 h. Then, the PANI coated films were washed by dilute HCl solution to remove unreacted monomers and other impurities from
the surface of the films. The final hydrogel BC/PANI composites were immersed in DI water.

sections.heading: 2.2. Characterization of BC/PANI nano-biocomposite
sections.text:
Chemical and crystalline structures of BC’s fibers before and after coating with PANI with different concentrations of monomers were analyzed by attenuated total reflectance fourier transform infrared (ATR-FTIR) spectroscopy (Shimadzu IR-Prestige 21, Japan) and x-ray diffraction (XRD) (Rigaku Ultima-IV), respectively. The morphologies of the composites were studied by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) (Hitachi S4800, Japan). For ATR-FTIR and FE-SEM, dry film was used and dry powder was prepared for XRD.
2.3. Microbial fuel cell configuration
An H-type dual-chamber MFC with working volume of 250 mL for each chamber was utilized throughout this work. Graphite plate (ENTEGRIS, INC. USA) was employed as a cathode (similar to work done by Mashkour et al. [25]) and BC/PANI nano-biocomposites were applied as anodes. Nafion 117 (Sigma Aldrich, USA) was treated with boiling in 3% H2O2, D.I water and 0.5 M H2SO4 similar to Ghasemi et al. Method [26] and then was used as proton exchange membrane between two chambers. All the anodes as well as the cathode were prepared in dimensions of 2 cm 4 cm and connected to very low-resistance copper wires for fast electron transfer in external circuit. The wires were not in direct contact with solution.

sections.heading: 2.4. Bacteria culture
sections.text: Anaerobic sludge from Ghaemshahr wastewater treatment complex located in north of Iran was utilized as inoculums. The mixed culture was grown in a 0.5 M phosphate buffer media consisted of 10 g of glucose, 3 g of yeast extract and 1 g of peptone per liter under 30 C for 12 h and in stationary phase. In order to remove oxygen and keep anaerobic condition, nitrogenwas purged for 20 min before adding inoculums.

sections.heading: 2.5. Electrochemical analysis
sections.text: Cyclic voltammetries (CVs) were accomplished by a Potentiostat/Galvanostat IVIUM (Vertex, Netherlands) at a standard threeelectrode cell in which anode was the working electrode and placed near the reference electrode (RE) (KCl saturated Ag/AgCl) and pt Standard electrode as the counter electrode (CE). Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) experiments were carried out over frequency range of 10 mHze100 kHz at OCP in the MFC device by putting RE at anode compartment.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of BC/PANI nano-bio composite
sections.text:
Successful synthesis of PANI on BC fibers was determined by both the fabricated films appearance (inset of Fig. 1) and ATR-FTIR spectroscopy (Fig. 1(A)). The spectra in ) ( display characteristic patterns of different concentrations of PANI in the composites. Absorption bands at 1470 and 1560 cm 1 are attributed to stretching vibration mode of C]C for quinonoid and benzenoid rings, respectively [24,27,28]. The characteristic bands of CeN stretching for benzene rings appear at 1284 cm 1 [27]. While absorption bands around 800 cm 1 show CeH aromatic stretching vibration [29]. As it can be seen, the intensities for bands at 1470
and 1560 cm 1 are approximately equal suggesting the satisfactory synthesis of conductive emeraldin, a form of PANI with equal amounts of quinonoid and benzenoid units [27], on BC’s fibers. In addition, the enhancement in the intensity of PANI peaks with increase in its concentration can represent a more concentrated synthesized PANI in the composites.
XRD patterns demonstrate the phase of cellulose І in BC and the fabricated BC/PANI composites by characteristic hkl planes of (110) and (200) observable in the patterns [30]. (Fig. 1(B)). BC XRD pattern shows that cellulose І has an estimated degree of crystallinity of about 94%, calculated by Segal’s equation [31]. The other
patterns at Fig. 1(B) ((a-d)) do not display considerable difference with respect to that of BC. Therefore, it can be deduced that the PANI did not change the crystalline structure of BC’s nanofibers. It is in agreement with previous research conducted by Muller et al. [24]. The above result can be attributed to low temperature (5 C) and weak acidic solution (0.5 M HCl) during polymerization, otherwise cellulose degrades in high temperature and strong acidic condition [32].
The morphologies of dried fabricated BC/PANI nanobiocomposites were examined via FE-SEM images (Fig. 2). The presence of PANI nano flakes entangled with BC nano-fibers can be observed. A suitable coating layer was achieved by in-situ polymerization of aniline. The thick layer of PANI particles tend to agglomerate with increasing PANI concentration. The polymer tends to coat the BC nano-fibers resulting in a continuous conducting pathway responsible for low resistance against electron transfer in the composites. Since all samples underwent the same polymerization, the thickness of the PANI layer seems to be determined by aniline initial concentration. In higher concentrations of PANI (Fig. 2C and D), the pores can hardly be seen in FE-SEM images. In fact, during drying process, the composites shrink and BC’s nano-fibers stick together [33]while the composites utilized as anodes in microbial fuel cell are at hydrogel state. Therefore, it is expected that the electrodes inworking state (wet) are porous with suitable pore size.

sections.heading: 3.2. BC as a hydrogel anode
sections.text:
MFC’s performance was studied in the presence of graphite and BC working anodes. Compared to graphite, BC indicated a two-fold increase in the power density of theMFC (Fig. 3(A)). In addition, the CV in Fig. 3(B) showed weak redox peaks for hydrogel BC in anode chamber of MFCwhile it was not seen for graphite. The above result may be due to the synergic effects of BC’s porosity (as can be seen in Fig. 3(C)) and buffer solution conductivity (50 mS) which helps BC’s extended nonconductor surface area be turned into a weak
f (a) 0.1; (b) 0.2; (c) 0.3; and (d) 0.4 M of aniline.
conductive one. While graphite as a commonly used electrode, contains suitable conductivity (50 S/cm), its restricted active surface (Fig. 3(D)) and lack of satisfactory electrochemical behavior impose limitation on its application as anode in MFC. It is noticeable that BC’s fibers may be decomposed in contact with microorganisms. So, it is necessary to cover its fibers with a protective and
conductive layer upon which lifetime and conductivity as well as electrochemical properties of BC is improved.

sections.heading: 3.3. Catalytic behavior of BC/PANI hydrogel electrodes
sections.text:
CV measurements of BC-PANI composites (Fig. 4(A)) were performed in anode chamber of MFC in anaerobic condition. Almost all CVs showed obvious redox peaks which are low in currents due mainly to the fact that a mediator-less MFC, and self-mediatory of mixed culture cells were applied. Catalytic behavior of polyaniline has been proved by the scientists [8]. As a proof of the concept in this study, increasing the concentration of polyaniline on BC’s fibers demonstrated enhancement in peak current intensity (Fig. 4(A)). Furthermore, CVs can also be used for comparing charge capacitance of the electrodes by integrating the area under obtained voltammograms [34]. As can be seen, higher concentrations of polyaniline led to more integrated areas and consequently more charge capacitance for the fabricated composites. It is highly in agreement with Wang et al. investigation [22]. For concentration above 0.4 M aniline CV did not follow mentioned trend (not shown in Fig. 4) which can be due to decreasing porosity and active sites of synthesized composite. In fact, by PANI coating on BC’s fibers they become conductive, but extra amount of the polymer fills voids between the fibers and reduces total available surface used for electrochemical reactions. The concept can also be interpreted by FE-SEM images (Fig. 2(b-d).
EIS analysis shown in Fig. 4(B) was performed to measure the impedance at the interface of anode electrode/anolyte which is
defined as charge transfer resistance (Rct) of anode. Rct of anode is the most important kinetic limitation because of slow rate of activation reaction on anode surface [35]. The experiment was performed in a double-chamber MFC and under three-electrode mode inwhich working electrode (BC/PANI) and reference electrodewere placed in anode chamber and graphite cathodewas used as counter electrode. Linear region of graphs with Slope of 45 in high frequencies was attributed to porosity of anodes and verify the porous nature of BC/PANI composites [8]. For more accurate interpretation of EIS graphs and calculating Rct, they were modeled by a Randles equivalent circuit by Ivium Potentiostat. Randles is a simple circuit and showed a minimal error (below 3%) for Rct calculation. In the model, Rct is achieved from the diameter of semicircle part of graph. The smaller diameter poses the faster electron transfer [36]. According to Fig. 4(B) and the afore-mentioned definition of Rct, increasing the concentration of the synthesized PANI on BC’s fibers resulted in better catalytic activity of anode in redox reactions and consequently reducing Rct of anode. Also, it is predictable that uncoated BC will have high resistance, even in hydrogel state. BC turned into a hydrogel conductive material by PANI coating. For BC/ PANI composites in hydrogel state. Rct achieved 589, 517, 372 and 280 U for concentration of 0.1, 0.2, 0.3 and 0.4 M of aniline, respectively.
to BC/PANI composites surface.

sections.heading: 3.4. BC/PANI composites’ performance as anodes in MFC
sections.text:
The performance of the as-synthesized BC/PANI composites were evaluated as anodes in mentioned H-type dual-chamber MFC device. The anodes (2 cm 4 cm) were made of 0.1, 0.2, 0.3 and 0.4 M aniline monomer respectively. Anodic compartment contained a suspension of growing mixed culture cells. Graphite as cathode was placed in phosphate buffer solution by which pH ¼ 7 for catholyte and required conductivity for charge (proton) transport were provided. Measuring current and power output of MFC were accomplished by means of a benchtop data logger (Danesh Gostar Hamgam ba Sanat, Iran) in which 46 different resistances (from 800 kU to 100 U) as external loads were exerted on MFC. With various aniline concentrations in composite anodes, the maximum power density output of the MFC continued to increase sharply from 0.1 to 0.3M of aniline and slowed down from0.3 to 0.4 of it (inset of Fig. 5(B)).
Moreover, polarization curves of the MFC are illustrated in Fig. 5(B). They are useful tools for calculating the internal resistance losses at MFCs. Internal resistance (Rin) as a defining characteristic for MFC consists of different resistances such as resistances of electrodes, electrolyte and membrane [37]. Among different methods for evaluating Rin, Polarization Slope which is defined at the linear region of polarization curve is more usual method [37]. Neglecting rapid voltage drop moieties in Fig. 5(B) (due to high external loads), the slope of second linear parts were measured as Rin. As can be seen in inset of Fig. 5(B), Rin of the composites decreased by increasing PANI concentrations. In other words, a dramatic drop was occurred by increasing the concentration of aniline from 0.1 to 0.3 M in BC/PANI synthesis process while from 0.3 to 0.4 M of Aniline concentration, Rin fell by a lower slope. It is notable that all components of the MFC except anode electrode were the same.
Maximum power density (mW/m2) of 46.19, 75.52, 105.58 and 117.76 were recorded at current density (mA/m2) of 225, 435, 583 and 616, respectively for 0.1, 0.2, 0.3 and 0.4 M of aniline (Fig. 5(A)). Therefore, in comparison with BC and graphite BC/PANI nanobiocoposites as anodes showed considerable improvements which make them capable of being viable alternative to conventional electrodes.

sections.heading: 3.5. Mixed culture cells behaviors on the surface of BC/PANI nanobiocomposites
sections.text:
Microorganisms as the palpitating heart of MFC’s technology require suitable conditions to be able to do their task as best as possible. In order to study the performance of anode composites, a 1 kU resistance was placed on external circuit of the MFC for 48 h. The FE-SEM images of anode surfaces (Fig. 6) illustrate reasonable adhesion of the microbes to BC/PANI composites. It can be attributed to suitable roughness, superhydrophilicity and positively charged surface of the composites [38,39]. Fabricated electrodes are hydrogel porous media composites admitting nutrients to be permanently accessible for microorganisms. Indeed, the main property of wet BC/PANI anode is its hydrogel and porous nature. Capillary between cellulosic fibers [40] facilitates soluble substrate transfer to inner bacterial bio film on the anode. In this regards, microorganisms can be alive and electrochemically active. The capillary find necessity once a dense biofilm is formed. For conventional electrodes, biofilm growth gives rise to decrease or even lack of nutrients for inner layers of microorganisms and spoilage of them [10]. Consequently, the inactive layer plays the role of a resistance and barrier against electron transfer from exoelectrogens
to anode surface. But these drawback were eliminated by using BC/ PANI composites.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: In this study, we propose a unique hydrogel BC/PANI nanobiocomposite with extended conductive specific surface area and suitable biocatalytic activity. Four different concentrations of aniline are applied in fabrication of the composites. Interpretation of the accomplished tests demonstrated that the slope of enhancing the performance of the MFC decreased in higher concentration of aniline. In comparison with conventional electrodes, BC/PANI due to its cellulosic, porous and hydrophilic nature of BC can improve the MFC device output in a mediator-less media of mixed culture cells with the help of PANI conductivity. Nutrient transfer can be facilitated by capillary between BC’s fibers which resulted in formation of an active biofilm as a high-performance bioanode. This hydrogel anode may also be enhanced by other modifiers and can be utilized in various configurations of MFCs in future works.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: The authors would like to sincerely thank all those who helped them finish this work especially Prof. Tsunehisa Kimura, Prof. Fumiko Kimura for preparing FE-SEM, ATR-FTIR and XRD at Kyoto University and Dr. Masoomeh Pourali for text editing.
